<dankrad> The problem is that for the executable beacon chain, we want *every* staker to run an Eth1 node, otherwise security will really be much worse (because we can get a majority chain on an incorrect Eth1 state transition otherwise, and we don't even have fraud proofs to stop it)

This is different once we have weak statelessness, because then running the Eth1 node will be cheap (only need to verify a block every now and then, not maintain state); and producing blocks will be much more expensive (need to run a stateful Eth1 node), so outsourcing makes a lot of sense and won't compromise security (re @n0ble: there should be an equilibrium between cost of running own eth1 node and transaction fees that the owner of the node can make. author: chat-bridge
content:
<dankrad> Just see the difference:
Current situation: Miners verify the state transitions. Miners invest millions in hardware and infrastructure, operational costs are similar to rewards. You can assume they have at least 10k+ operations cost per month, but most are likely only profitable at 1M+. State verification needs a single Eth1 node for them, which has a running cost of maybe 10-100$ per month. If they don't do it, they risk their blocks being orphaned, which is losing 1000s of $ per block.
Post-merge: Validators verify the state transitions. The operational cost of running a validator at home is cost of hardware (can get it for <200$) plus electricity and internet connection (<50$/month). Adding a full Eth1 node costs maybe 500$ in hardware and doubles your electricity cost. So not trivial at all. In my case, I eventually outsourced Eth1 to a dedicated server because it just clogged up my internet connection too much (which to be fair wouldn't be a problem if you're only doing verification)
Cost of not verifying: You may very occasionally vote for the wrong head, if someone produces an incorrect block. Each (very rare) time this happens you would lose $0.01 (one cent) in rewards at current prices

<dankrad> BTW, if we think that proof of custody is too hard/harsh, there is also the opposite/gold coin approach to rewarding running an eth1 node. your custody secret could point to a random eth1 address (gotta make this highly dependent on the most recent transactions, so that you have to recompute) and with a certain value, you win a reward of 1 eth, distributed such that the expected value is ca. 1/3 of current rewards or so.
Nice thing is that the gold coin approach does not require custody key reveals, as it's a voluntary action
